channel.title: SSH Webclient
channel.description:
I need to use SSH from school to access my webserver but I think they have a whitelist policy and only allow port 80 for websites, and maybe a few others. This means I can't use PuTTY or anything, and normal SSH webclients don't work because it's still trying to access a server on port 22, which is blocked.
This website works by proxying the session, but I'd have to pay a subscription and I'm still paranoid about them keeping my details: http://www.gotossh.com/
Is there an app I could put on the server which can be accessed via the web, but does the same thing as normal SSH? I would make it myself, but execution permissions are very difficult in PHP and barely work for me.

item.title: SSH Webclient
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

That’s exactly what I was looking for, thanks! I’ll try to get it working, if not then I’ll try hosting on port 443 because I’m pretty sure they allow https.

Read full topic

item.title: SSH Webclient
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

There is a PHP-CGI app that will let you ssh to your own server from a web page, with the connection coming from the server, not your client’s computer (in this case the school). I’ve never tried it, but it seems to be what you want.

edit: I can’t find the program you are looking for, but you could write your own with this fairly easily:
http://kevin.vanzonneveld.net/techblog/article/make_ssh_connections_with_php/
I’ll try to find the one you want though…

edit2: They probably allow HTTPS too, right? (port 443) Set ssh to listen over that?

Read full topic

item.title: SSH Webclient
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

cooper:

Maybe I’ve misunderstood, but couldn’t you just change the port the SSH server is on to one that’s not blocked?

Well as I say, I think they have a whitelist policy because I’ve tried a few ports and only 80 works (which is web, and I have a webserver…).

Are there any port ranges windows must have open to use the internet which I can use?

Read full topic
